newsitem.title: USA: U.S. issues rare license for food sale to N.Korea.
newsitem.headline: U.S. issues rare license for food sale to N.Korea.

text.p: The U.S. Treasury has given a Minneapolis firm permission to export 500,000 tonnes of food to famine-struck North Korea, a U.S. official said on Monday, a week after the communist nation apologised for a submarine incursion into South Korean waters.

The Treasury granted a license to Minneapolis-based Cargill Inc., a giant grain company that received the first authorisation to barter grain with North Korea in years. The step was viewed by analysts on Monday as a warming in relations between the Stalinist nation and the United States.
Only a handful of U.S. license have allowed food sales to communist North Korea and none recently, a Treasury official said.
Cargill, which applied last September for the license, said on Monday it allowed sale of wheat and rice.

Some grain-trade sources were sceptical a deal would be struck with Pyongyang, which was believed to have little money for direct food purchases. Barters are difficult to arrange and can be risky financially, they said.
Analysts said the license for Cargill seemed enmeshed in efforts to rein in North Korea's suspected nuclear weapons programme and to ease military tension on the Korean peninsula.
The (U.S.) State Department said it hoped North Korea's apology would lead to action on several issues involving North Korea.
While Cargill said its license was issued on Dec. 30, the day after North Korea apologised, U.S. officials did not confirm the approval until Monday.

"It (the license) is significant in the sense that the United States has had a trade embargo" with North Korea, said Victor Cha, a Georgetown University professor who specialises in East Asian and Korean issues.
The United States has moved slowly on normalising relations with North Korea.
North Korea suffered two years of flooding that depleted its food supplies and left its citizens short of food. The United States gave $2 million in February 1996 to alleviate famine.

Buying all the grain authorised by the Cargill license could easily cost $100 million, based on U.S. prices and shipping costs. Grain analysts said high U.S. prices might force Cargill to fill an order with grain from other nations.
Despite its food problems North Korea is a producer of coal, iron ore, magnesite, graphite, copper, zinc, lead and precious metals. It exports some minerals and metallurgical products.
Along with being one of the world's leading grain traders, Cargill is active in all major commodities, including metals, so-called soft commodites, meats, salt and others.
Cha said zinc, a widely traded metal, might be of interest for a barter. North Korea "could be of longer interest," to Cargill, he said, "just getting market access."
The United States has said it regards North Korea's nuclear programme as one of the major threats to peace in East Asia.
